title: Europe’s New Sovereignty Target – US Payment Giants
content: After AI chips and cloud computing, Europeans have woken up to another American dominated technology to worry about –payment systems operated by Visa and Mastercard. title: Power in Numbers: Governments Gang Up On Tech
content: It was a global counterattack. After AI chatbot Grok started producing fake sexualized images, the European Commission warned of an investigation. UK regulator Ofcom launched a formal investigation. Brazil considered a ban. Malaysia and Indonesia went ahead and blocked the chatbot. Even in the US, California’s Attorney General sent a cease and desist letter. Grok surrendered. title: Europe Needs a Military Operations Center in Ukraine
content: Russia is fighting two wars at once: a brutal war in Ukraine and a persistent hybrid war across the European continent. That gray-zone conflict increasingly uses the air, space, and cyber domains — along with criminals and biker gangs — to probe, destabilize, and undermine European resolve. If and when a peace deal is finalized, this pressure will not cease; it will intensify. title: Where Will Italy Side in a NATO Divorce?
content: Whether or not you agree with Canada’s Prime Minister Mark Carney that the old world order is rupturing, there’s no question it’s under huge strain. With the Trump administration making clear through statements and policy papers that Europe is very largely on its own, the continent’s bigger powers are facing deeply uncomfortable choices. title: Korea Rivals Taiwan in Chip Prowess
content: Although Taiwan’s Silicon Shield dominates global semiconductor manufacturing, South Korea is catching up and becoming equally indispensable. The key Korean advantage centers on high-performance memory chips. It is one of only three countries (with Taiwan and the US) able to manufacture these crucial leading‑edge chips, making it a chokepoint. title: The Start of the End? The End of New START
content: It is a historic moment, and not in a good way — on February 5, the last remaining bilateral treaty between the United States and Russia limiting strategic nuclear arms — New START — will expire, and the path to unconstrained nuclear competition will be unimpeded. title: Europe Is Alone — Now What?
content: Russia’s four-year-long war of aggression against Ukraine menaces Europe. With the US now stating that regional security is primarily an issue for the continent itself, there remains a still-unanswered question — who will take on this role? There are three outline alternatives, and each offers its own problems and strengths. title: The Scramble for the Arctic — Greenland and Beyond
content: The latter third of the 19th century saw a vast European “scramble for Africa,” as advances in technology, medicine, and communications allowed European explorers and colonizers to penetrate deeper into the heretofore impenetrable interior of the continent. title: Europe Should Exploit Georgia’s Regime Ructions
content: The latest fracture in Georgia’s elite came on January 12, when former primed minister Irakli Garibashvili was jailed for five years after pleading guilty to money-laundering. title: The Internet, Switched Off
content: When Iranians revolted, their government cut them off from the world. Mobile networks degraded first. Fixed-line disruptions followed. Instead of cutting cables, the authorities interfered with routing and key protocols. As Iran shut down the Internet, Revolutionary Guards crushed the protests, killing thousands.
